It is difficult to predict whether less embraced ideas from the Renaissance will experience a resurgence in popularity in the future. However, history has shown that ideas and movements often go in and out of favor over time.

For example, the idea of civic duty and citizenship that was central to civic humanism has gained renewed attention in recent years, with movements promoting greater civic engagement and participation in politics. The idea of the common good, which was central to republican political philosophy, has also seen renewed interest in some circles as a counterpoint to individualism and self-interest.

Similarly, the idea of political theology has resurfaced in recent years with the growing influence of religious and fundamentalist movements on politics across the world. Some thinkers have argued that exploring the relationship between religion, morality, and politics may be necessary for addressing contemporary political challenges.

Overall, while it is difficult to predict the future popularity of specific ideas, it is possible that some of the less embraced ideas from the Renaissance may see renewed interest and engagement as societies continue to evolve and confront new political challenges.
